pretext: Besides the basic consonant-vowel combinations in hiragana, markers can be added to the characters to change their sound. These markers are known as dakuten/handakuten and they are these small dots and circles added on the upper right of a basic hiragana character. Dakuten (゛) and handakuten (゜). Colloquially, dakuten is called “ten-ten” which literally means “dot-dot” or “dots”, and handakuten is known as “maru” which means “circle”.

prompt: In Japanese, you can turn “K” sounds into “G” sounds by adding dakuten (゛) to their characters.
Those were the “G” sounds in hiragana. To recap:
Let’s learn a word that utilizes “G” sounds as well as a couple of the characters we’ve already learned. “Hi-ra-ga-na” uses the consonant-vowels “Hi” (ひ) “Ra” (ら) “Ga” (が) “Na” (な).
